title: Python Programming - Complete Comprehensive Guide
content:
🐍 Python Programming - Complete & Comprehensive Guide

Master Python from basics to advanced concepts with detailed explanations, real code examples, step-by-step instructions, and practical demonstrations.

📖 1. Introduction to Python

What is Python?

Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity and readability. It emphasizes code readability and uses whitespace for indentation, making it beginner-friendly while powerful for advanced users.

Why Learn Python?

  • Easy to Learn: Simple syntax similar to English
  • Versatile: Used in web development, data science, AI/ML, automation, and more
  • Large Community: Extensive libraries and frameworks available
  • High Demand: One of the most sought-after programming languages
  • Career Growth: Opens doors to many career paths

Installation & Setup

Step 1: Download Python from python.org

Step 2: Run the installer and check "Add Python to PATH"

Step 3: Verify installation: python --version

Step 4: Test Python: python >>> print("Hello, Python!") >>> exit()

Your First Python Program

# Save as hello.py
print("Hello, World!")
name = input("What is your name? ")
print(f"Welcome, {name}!")

Run: python hello.py

💾 2. Variables and Data Types

Understanding Variables

Variables are containers that store data values. Python is dynamically typed, so no explicit type declaration needed.

Variable Naming Rules

  • Must start with letter or underscore
  • Can contain letters, numbers, and underscores
  • Case-sensitive (name and Name are different)
  • Avoid Python keywords (if, for, while, etc.)

Code Examples

# Single variable assignment
name = "Alice"
age = 25
height = 5.7
is_student = True

# Multiple assignment
x, y, z = 1, 2, 3

# Check type
print(type(name))      # <class 'str'>
print(type(age))       # <class 'int'>
print(type(height))    # <class 'float'>

Python Data Types

# String
text = "Python is awesome"

# Integer
count = 42
negative = -10

# Float
pi = 3.14159

# Boolean
is_valid = True
is_empty = False

# None (absence of value)
result = None

# Complex
complex_num = 3 + 4j

Type Conversion

# Convert to string
num = 42
num_str = str(num)  # "42"

# Convert to integer
price = float("99.99")  # 99.99
price_int = int(price)  # 99

# Convert to float
score = 85
score_float = float(score)  # 85.0

# Convert to boolean
zero = bool(0)  # False
one = bool(1)   # True

Common Pitfall & Solution

❌ Pitfall: String concatenation with numbers

age = 25
print("Age: " + age)  # TypeError!

✅ Solution: Convert or use f-string

age = 25
print(f"Age: {age}")  # Correct and recommended

➕ 3. Operators

Arithmetic Operators

a = 10
b = 3

addition = a + b        # 13
subtraction = a - b     # 7
multiplication = a * b  # 30
division = a / b        # 3.333...
floor_division = a // b # 3
modulus = a % b         # 1
exponent = a ** b       # 1000

Comparison Operators

x = 5
y = 10

print(x == y)  # False
print(x != y)  # True
print(x < y)   # True
print(x <= y)  # True

Logical Operators

a = True
b = False

print(a and b)  # False
print(a or b)   # True
print(not a)    # False

# Real-world example
age = 25
income = 50000

if age >= 18 and income >= 30000:
    print("Eligible for loan")

Assignment Operators

x = 10
x += 5      # x = 15
x -= 3      # x = 12
x *= 2      # x = 24
x /= 4      # x = 6.0
x //= 2     # x = 3.0

📝 4. String Operations

Creating and Accessing Strings

text = "Python Programming"

# Access characters
first_char = text[0]        # 'P'
last_char = text[-1]        # 'g'
substring = text[0:6]       # 'Python'

# String length
length = len(text)          # 18

String Methods

text = "Hello World"

# Case conversion
upper = text.upper()           # "HELLO WORLD"
lower = text.lower()           # "hello world"
capitalize = text.capitalize() # "Hello world"

# Searching
index = text.find("World")     # 6
count = text.count("o")        # 2

# Replacement
new_text = text.replace("World", "Python")

# Splitting and joining
words = text.split()           # ["Hello", "World"]
joined = "-".join(words)       # "Hello-World"

String Formatting

name = "Alice"
age = 25
salary = 50000.5

# f-strings (recommended)
print(f"Name: {name}, Age: {age}")
print(f"Salary: ${salary:.2f}")  # "Salary: $50000.50"
print(f"Age doubled: {age * 2}")  # "Age doubled: 50"

📊 5. Lists and Collections

Lists - Ordered, Mutable Collections

# Creating lists
empty_list = []
numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
mixed = [1, "two", 3.0, True]

# Accessing elements
first = numbers[0]          # 1
last = numbers[-1]          # 5
slice = numbers[1:4]        # [2, 3, 4]

List Methods

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "orange"]

# Adding elements
fruits.append("grape")
fruits.insert(1, "mango")
fruits.extend(["kiwi"])

# Removing elements
removed = fruits.pop()      # Remove last
fruits.remove("orange")     # Remove by value

# Finding and sorting
index = fruits.index("banana")
numbers = [3, 1, 4]
numbers.sort()  # [1, 3, 4]

Tuples - Immutable Collections

# Creating tuples
coordinates = (10, 20)
single = (1,)  # Note the comma!

# Access like lists
x = coordinates[0]  # 10

# Unpacking
def get_user():
    return ("Alice", 25, "alice@example.com")

name, age, email = get_user()

Dictionaries - Key-Value Pairs

# Creating dictionaries
person = {
    "name": "Alice",
    "age": 25,
    "city": "New York"
}

# Accessing
name = person["name"]
age = person.get("age")
job = person.get("job", "Unknown")

# Modifying
person["age"] = 26
person["email"] = "alice@example.com"
del person["city"]

# Iterating
for key, value in person.items():
    print(f"{key}: {value}")

Sets - Unordered, Unique Collections

# Creating sets
colors = {"red", "green", "blue"}
unique_nums = set([1, 2, 2, 3])  # {1, 2, 3}

# Adding and removing
colors.add("yellow")
colors.discard("red")

# Set operations
set1 = {1, 2, 3}
set2 = {2, 3, 4}
union = set1 | set2        # {1, 2, 3, 4}
intersection = set1 & set2  # {2, 3}
difference = set1 - set2   # {1}

🔀 6. Control Flow (if, elif, else)

Basic if-else

age = 25

if age >= 18:
    print("You are an adult")
else:
    print("You are a minor")

if-elif-else

score = 85

if score >= 90:
    grade = "A"
elif score >= 80:
    grade = "B"
elif score >= 70:
    grade = "C"
else:
    grade = "F"

Nested Conditions

age = 25
has_license = True

if age >= 18:
    if has_license:
        print("You can drive")
    else:
        print("Get a license first")
else:
    print("Too young to drive")

Ternary Operator

age = 25
status = "Adult" if age >= 18 else "Minor"
print(status)  # "Adult"

🔁 7. Loops (for and while)

for Loops

# Loop through list
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "orange"]
for fruit in fruits:
    print(fruit)

# Loop with index
for index, fruit in enumerate(fruits):
    print(f"{index}: {fruit}")

# Loop through range
for i in range(5):          # 0, 1, 2, 3, 4
    print(i)

# Loop with step
for i in range(0, 10, 2):   # 0, 2, 4, 6, 8
    print(i)

# Loop through dictionary
person = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
for key, value in person.items():
    print(f"{key}: {value}")

while Loops

count = 0
while count < 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1

# Infinite loop with break
while True:
    user_input = input("Enter 'quit' to exit: ")
    if user_input == "quit":
        break
    print(f"You entered: {user_input}")

Loop Control: break and continue

# break - exits loop
for i in range(10):
    if i == 5:
        break
    print(i)  # 0, 1, 2, 3, 4

# continue - skips iteration
for i in range(10):
    if i % 2 == 0:
        continue
    print(i)  # 1, 3, 5, 7, 9

else with Loops

# else executes when loop completes normally
for i in range(5):
    print(i)
else:
    print("Loop completed!")  # Prints

# else with break doesn't execute
for i in range(5):
    if i == 3:
        break
else:
    print("Loop completed!")  # Doesn't print

⚙️ 8. Functions

Defining and Calling Functions

# Basic function
def greet():
    print("Hello, World!")

greet()

# Function with parameters
def greet_person(name):
    print(f"Hello, {name}!")

greet_person("Alice")

# Function with return value
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

result = add(5, 3)
print(result)  # 8

Default Parameters

def greet(name="Guest"):
    print(f"Hello, {name}!")

greet()           # Hello, Guest!
greet("Alice")    # Hello, Alice!

# Multiple defaults
def create_profile(name, age=18, city="Unknown"):
    print(f"Name: {name}, Age: {age}, City: {city}")

create_profile("Alice")

*args and **kwargs

# *args - variable positional arguments
def sum_all(*args):
    return sum(args)

print(sum_all(1, 2, 3))         # 6
print(sum_all(1, 2, 3, 4, 5))   # 15

# **kwargs - variable keyword arguments
def print_info(**kwargs):
    for key, value in kwargs.items():
        print(f"{key}: {value}")

print_info(name="Alice", age=25, city="NYC")

Return Multiple Values

# Return tuple
def get_user_info():
    name = "Alice"
    age = 25
    email = "alice@example.com"
    return name, age, email

# Unpack
name, age, email = get_user_info()
print(f"{name}, {age}, {email}")

Scope and Global Variables

global_var = "I'm global"

def my_function():
    local_var = "I'm local"
    print(global_var)    # Can access global
    print(local_var)     # Can access local

my_function()

# Modify global
def modify_global():
    global global_var
    global_var = "Modified"

modify_global()
print(global_var)  # "Modified"

Common Pitfall & Solution

❌ Pitfall: Mutable default arguments

def add_item(item, list=[]):
    list.append(item)
    return list

print(add_item(1))   # [1]
print(add_item(2))   # [1, 2] - Bug!

✅ Solution: Use None as default

def add_item(item, list=None):
    if list is None:
        list = []
    list.append(item)
    return list

🎯 9. Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)

Classes and Objects

# Define class
class Person:
    def __init__(self, name, age):
        self.name = name
        self.age = age
    
    def introduce(self):
        return f"My name is {self.name} and I'm {self.age}"

# Create objects
person1 = Person("Alice", 25)
person2 = Person("Bob", 30)

# Access
print(person1.name)           # Alice
print(person1.introduce())    # My name is Alice and I'm 25

Inheritance

class Animal:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name
    
    def speak(self):
        return "Some sound"

class Dog(Animal):
    def speak(self):  # Override
        return f"{self.name} barks: Woof!"

class Cat(Animal):
    def speak(self):
        return f"{self.name} meows: Meow!"

dog = Dog("Buddy")
cat = Cat("Whiskers")

print(dog.speak())  # Buddy barks: Woof!
print(cat.speak())  # Whiskers meows: Meow!

Encapsulation - Private Attributes

class BankAccount:
    def __init__(self, balance):
        self.__balance = balance  # Private
    
    def deposit(self, amount):
        if amount > 0:
            self.__balance += amount
            return f"Deposited ${amount}"
        return "Invalid"
    
    def withdraw(self, amount):
        if 0 < amount <= self.__balance:
            self.__balance -= amount
            return f"Withdrew ${amount}"
        return "Invalid"
    
    def get_balance(self):
        return self.__balance

account = BankAccount(1000)
print(account.deposit(500))
print(account.get_balance())

Practical Example: Student Management

class Student:
    def __init__(self, name, student_id):
        self.name = name
        self.student_id = student_id
        self.grades = []
    
    def add_grade(self, grade):
        if 0 <= grade <= 100:
            self.grades.append(grade)
            return f"Grade {grade} added"
        return "Invalid grade"
    
    def get_average(self):
        return sum(self.grades) / len(self.grades) if self.grades else 0
    
    def get_status(self):
        avg = self.get_average()
        if avg >= 90:
            return "A - Excellent"
        elif avg >= 80:
            return "B - Good"
        elif avg >= 70:
            return "C - Average"
        else:
            return "F - Failing"

student = Student("Alice", "STU001")
student.add_grade(85)
student.add_grade(90)
print(f"Average: {student.get_average():.2f}")
print(f"Status: {student.get_status()}")

📂 10. File Handling

Reading Files

# Read entire file
with open("file.txt", "r") as file:
    content = file.read()
    print(content)

# Read line by line
with open("file.txt", "r") as file:
    for line in file:
        print(line.strip())

# Read all lines
with open("file.txt", "r") as file:
    lines = file.readlines()

Writing to Files

# Write (overwrites)
with open("file.txt", "w") as file:
    file.write("Hello, World!
")
    file.write("Python is awesome!")

# Append (adds to existing)
with open("file.txt", "a") as file:
    file.write("
New line added")

Working with CSV

import csv

# Read CSV
with open("data.csv", "r") as file:
    csv_reader = csv.reader(file)
    for row in csv_reader:
        print(row)

# Write CSV
data = [
    ["Name", "Age", "City"],
    ["Alice", 25, "NYC"],
    ["Bob", 30, "LA"]
]

with open("data.csv", "w", newline="") as file:
    csv_writer = csv.writer(file)
    csv_writer.writerows(data)

Working with JSON

import json

# Read JSON
with open("data.json", "r") as file:
    data = json.load(file)

# Write JSON
person = {
    "name": "Alice",
    "age": 25,
    "city": "NYC"
}

with open("person.json", "w") as file:
    json.dump(person, file, indent=4)

🚨 11. Exception Handling

try-except Blocks

# Basic handling
try:
    num = int("abc")
except ValueError:
    print("Invalid input!")

# Multiple exceptions
try:
    result = 10 / int(input("Enter a number: "))
except ValueError:
    print("Please enter a valid number")
except ZeroDivisionError:
    print("Cannot divide by zero")

else and finally

# else and finally
try:
    file = open("data.txt", "r")
    content = file.read()
except FileNotFoundError:
    print("File not found!")
else:
    print("File read successfully")
finally:
    print("Cleanup code")  # Always executes

Raising Exceptions

def validate_age(age):
    if age < 0:
        raise ValueError("Age cannot be negative")
    if age > 150:
        raise ValueError("Invalid age")
    return f"Age {age} is valid"

try:
    print(validate_age(-5))
except ValueError as e:
    print(f"Error: {e}")

📚 12. Comprehensions

List Comprehension

# Simple list
squares = [x**2 for x in range(10)]

# With condition
evens = [x for x in range(10) if x % 2 == 0]

# Transform
fruits = ["apple", "banana", "orange"]
upper_fruits = [f.upper() for f in fruits]

Dictionary Comprehension

# Create dictionary
squares_dict = {x: x**2 for x in range(5)}

# From lists
names = ["Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"]
ages = [25, 30, 28]
people = {n: a for n, a in zip(names, ages)}

Set Comprehension

# Create set
unique_squares = {x**2 for x in [1, 1, 2, 2, 3]}

# Filter
unique_evens = {x for x in range(10) if x % 2 == 0}

📦 13. Modules and Imports

Importing Modules

import math
print(math.sqrt(16))

from math import sqrt, pi
print(sqrt(16))

# With alias
import numpy as np

Common Built-in Modules

from datetime import datetime, timedelta
now = datetime.now()

import random
random_int = random.randint(1, 10)
random_choice = random.choice([1, 2, 3])

import os
current_dir = os.getcwd()
files = os.listdir(".")

✨ 14. Decorators

Function Decorators

def my_decorator(func):
    def wrapper():
        print("Before function")
        func()
        print("After function")
    return wrapper

@my_decorator
def say_hello():
    print("Hello!")

say_hello()

Decorators with Arguments

def my_decorator(func):
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        print(f"Calling {func.__name__}")
        result = func(*args, **kwargs)
        return result
    return wrapper

@my_decorator
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

add(5, 3)

🔄 15. Generators

Creating Generators

def count_up(max):
    count = 1
    while count <= max:
        yield count
        count += 1

for num in count_up(5):
    print(num)  # 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

def fibonacci(n):
    a, b = 0, 1
    for _ in range(n):
        yield a
        a, b = b, a + b

for num in fibonacci(10):
    print(num)

🎓 16. Best Practices & Tips

Code Style (PEP 8)

  • Use meaningful names: user_name instead of un
  • Keep functions small and focused
  • Use comments for complex logic
  • Naming conventions:
    • Variables: lowercase_with_underscores
    • Classes: CamelCase
    • Constants: UPPERCASE_WITH_UNDERSCORES
  • Maximum line length: 79 characters

Documentation

def calculate_age(birth_year):
    # Calculate age from birth year
    # Args: birth_year (int)
    # Returns: int - Age in years
    return 2025 - birth_year

Error Handling Best Practices

try:
    result = int("abc")
except ValueError:
    print("Invalid input")

import logging
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

try:
    risky_operation()
except Exception as e:
    logger.error(f"Failed: {e}")
    raise

Performance Tips

  • Use list comprehensions instead of loops
  • Use generators for large datasets
  • Avoid global variables
  • Use built-in functions (optimized)

Debugging Tips

# Print statements
print(f"Value: {value}")

# Debugger
import pdb
pdb.set_trace()

# Type checking
print(type(variable))

# Help
help(function_name)

📝 Quick Reference

  • Variables: Store data values
  • Data Types: str, int, float, bool, list, tuple, dict, set
  • Operators: +, -, *, /, //, %, **, ==, !=, <, >, and, or
  • Control: if, elif, else, for, while, break, continue
  • Functions: def, return, *args, **kwargs
  • Collections: lists, tuples, dicts, sets
  • OOP: class, inheritance, encapsulation
  • Exceptions: try, except, else, finally, raise
  • Modules: import, from...import
  • Comprehensions: list, dict, set comprehensions

🎉 You've mastered Python fundamentals!
Keep practicing and exploring to become an expert Python programmer!
Practice Tips: Write code daily, build projects, read others' code, and contribute to open source.

title: Robot Framework - Complete Guide
content:
ü§ñ Robot Framework - Complete & Comprehensive Guide

Master keyword-driven test automation with Robot Framework. This guide covers everything from setup to advanced test suites, with code samples, best practices, and troubleshooting tips.

üìñ 1. Introduction to Robot Framework

What is Robot Framework?

Robot Framework is an open-source automation framework for acceptance testing and robotic process automation (RPA). It uses easy-to-read plain text syntax and supports keyword-driven testing.

Why Use Robot Framework?

  • Keyword-driven syntax (easy for non-programmers)
  • Extensible with libraries (Selenium, Requests, Database, etc.)
  • Readable test cases
  • Supports data-driven and behavior-driven testing

‚öôÔ∏è 2. Installation & Setup

Install Robot Framework

pip install robotframework

Install SeleniumLibrary (for web automation)

pip install robotframework-seleniumlibrary

Verify Installation

robot --version

üóÇÔ∏è 3. Test Suite Structure

Robot Framework test cases are written in .robot files using tabular format.

*** Settings ***
Library    SeleniumLibrary

*** Variables ***
${URL}     https://example.com

*** Test Cases ***
Open Browser And Check Title
    Open Browser    ${URL}    Chrome
    Title Should Be    Example Domain
    Close Browser

üîë 4. Variables

*** Variables ***
${USERNAME}    user
${PASSWORD}    pass
${LOGIN_URL}   https://example.com/login

üìù 5. Keywords

Keywords are reusable actions. You can use built-in, library, or user-defined keywords.

*** Keywords ***
Login To Application
    [Arguments]    ${username}    ${password}
    Input Text    id=username    ${username}
    Input Text    id=password    ${password}
    Click Button    id=submit

üåê 6. SeleniumLibrary Usage

*** Settings ***
Library    SeleniumLibrary

*** Test Cases ***
Search Google
    Open Browser    https://google.com    Chrome
    Input Text    name=q    Robot Framework
    Click Button    name=btnK
    Page Should Contain    Robot Framework
    Close Browser

üîó 7. RequestsLibrary Usage (API Testing)

*** Settings ***
Library    RequestsLibrary

*** Test Cases ***
Get API Response
    Create Session    api    https://jsonplaceholder.typicode.com
    ${resp}=    Get Request    api    /posts/1
    Should Be Equal As Strings    ${resp.status_code}    200
    Log    ${resp.json()}

üîÑ 8. Control Structures

*** Test Cases ***
Loop Example
    :FOR    ${item}    IN    one    two    three
    \    Log    ${item}

Conditional Example
    ${status}=    Set Variable    pass
    Run Keyword If    '${status}' == 'pass'    Log    Success
    ...    ELSE    Log    Failure

‚öôÔ∏è 9. Setup and Teardown

*** Test Cases ***
Test With Setup And Teardown
    [Setup]    Open Browser    https://example.com    Chrome
    Title Should Be    Example Domain
    [Teardown]    Close Browser

üß™ 10. Writing Real-World Test Example

*** Test Cases ***
Login Test
    Open Browser    ${LOGIN_URL}    Chrome
    Input Text    id=username    ${USERNAME}
    Input Text    id=password    ${PASSWORD}
    Click Button    id=submit
    Page Should Contain    Welcome
    Close Browser

üõ°Ô∏è 11. Best Practices

  • Use variables for URLs, credentials, and test data
  • Organize keywords for reusability
  • Keep test cases short and focused
  • Use setup/teardown for environment management
  • Log important actions and results

‚ö†Ô∏è 12. Common Pitfalls & Solutions

  • Element not found:
    Solution: Use waits (e.g., Wait Until Element Is Visible)
  • Hardcoded values:
    Solution: Use variables and resource files
  • Test flakiness:
    Solution: Use robust locators and proper setup/teardown

üì¶ 13. Advanced Features

  • Data-driven testing with Test Template
  • Resource files for shared keywords
  • Custom Python libraries
  • Parallel execution with pabot

üß≠ Quick Reference

  • Install: pip install robotframework
  • Run: robot tests/
  • Library: SeleniumLibrary, RequestsLibrary
  • Test Case: *** Test Cases ***
  • Keyword: *** Keywords ***
  • Variable: *** Variables ***

üéâ You've mastered Robot Framework fundamentals!
Practice by writing keyword-driven tests, automating web and API scenarios, and exploring advanced features.
Practice Tips: Refactor keywords, use resource files, and contribute to open source.
